answers.text: The collation of all known variants of a text

qas.question: What is the purpose of a variorum?

answers.text: so that a reader can track how textual decisions have been made in the preparation of a text for publication

qas.question: Name one author who is less frequently the subject of a variorum.
Name two works that are often the subject of a variorum.

answers.text: The Bible and the works of William Shakespeare

qas.question: What is the name for the collation of all unknown variants of a text?
What is it called when the variations are texts are read separately?
What book wasn't a product of variorum?
What author wasn't part of a variorum?
Leaves of Grass did not undergo what process?

context: <a0_0>The collation of all known variants of a text<a0_0/> is referred to as a <b4_0><b5_0>variorum<b5_0/><b4_0/>, namely a work of textual criticism whereby all variations and emendations are set side by side <a1_0>so that a reader can track how textual decisions have been made in the preparation of a text for publication<a1_0/>. <a3_0>The <b6_0>Bible<b6_0/> and the works of <b7_0>William Shakespeare<b7_0/><a3_0/> have often been the subjects of <b8_0>variorum<b8_0/> editions, although the same techniques have been applied with less frequency to many other works, such as Walt Whitman's Leaves of Grass, and the prose writings of <a2_0>Edward Fitzgerald<a2_0/>.
